name: One Hundred and One Damnations
description: Thousand cuts style

name: Shadows of the Sun v1.2
description:
v1.2: Closed Accounts is out while I focus on better, more taxing ice. I think Ichi 2.0 could be the winning splash in this deck so long as its out before D4v1d. If I see the Big D being too prevalent I'll swap it out for a 1.0 and maybe another Eli.

v1.1: Closed accounts is down to 1 to free up influence for a second Lotus Field. I needed more hard ETR ice that isn't in D4v1d range, and besides, you can always just tutor for the CA with an Atlas token if you absolutely have to. Chimera is also out to make room for two copies of Interns to bring back either of the two grids in a pinch.

The ice is nastier. The Oversight AI is real. The Scorch is a mercy.

This version of Blue Sun has teeth, and it relies on OAI as raw fuel for its economic engine. Pop it on your costly pieces of ice-- Curtain Wall, Janus, Tollbooth if you must though that isn't preferable -- and call them back to get free money. Fly your two Data Ravens to whichever server needs protecting, but plan on keeping at least one over HQ if you have a Crisium Grid installed. That's because once you build up your taxing fortress servers, just one simple Closed Accounts is all it takes to shut the runner out. And scoring the Eden Fragment almost makes this deck laughably good.

Plan on having a heavily stacked HQ because once Crisium Grid gets online behind an ice fortress there, accessing the remote in which you've loaded Off The Grid becomes an absolute bear. Trashing OTG will require two successful runs on HQ with an additional tax of 5c to trash the Crisium on the first run. That means with even one Data Raven and a Crisium on HQ they can't make the runs to clear Off The Grid and access your remote without clearing the two tags they rack up. Then you either dropped a Closed Accounts to lock them out of your servers on future runs, or they need to hope you don't have the double Scorched in hand.

I've debated either swapping the Tollbooth for a third Data Raven, or actually dropping the Closed Accounts for another Lotus Field + another Wall of Thorns, but I think for now this is how the deck will stay.

I'd love to hear your thoughts.

name: Nasir Meidan - The Space Rogue v 0.5
description:
So this is the alpha version of a deck, which I really want to try out. As of now I still don't have my hands on the cards in the 3rd data pack, so no testing can be done.

I think the general idea is pretty obvious, here is what is different though:

1) you use The Toolbox for extra recurring credits.

2) you use Nasir's ability and Personal Workshop to push out heavy stuff early games ( let alone if the opponent is playing some Bad Pub cards lol)

3) Once you setup everything through mid game, you should be able to break in anywhere with the recurring credits and the efficiency of the Stealth Breakers

4) Cyber Solutions Mem chip instead of Akematsu, because they will be easier to install via Personal Workshop than normally and because you would need minimum 6 memory for 3x Cloak + 3x Breakers let alone Imp and Cache

Things that I'm thinking about:

1) get Legwork and 3x SoT to put HQ pressure in late game ( I have this in my "normal" recurring credits Nasir and it won me a couple of games already). However to do this, I need to thin out some spaces ( maybe an Aesop or Cyber Solutions Mem chip), which is impossible without some play testing. Maybe put in a Nerve Agent If I can't thin out.

2) Not sure if Imp will pay off. The General idea is that many people allow Nassir early game to run free and on many occasions in my games so far I really wished I had an imp in my deck to punish them even harder in those early "free" runs. However, I also found out that Parasite is great in Nasir as well as data-sucker, so maybe they will replace the Imp.

3) Another idea is Keyhole. However, I feel it has a counter-efficiency with a deck that runs Indexing and R&D interface...

As always, if you have any questions and comments, go ahead =)

P.s. Oh yeah, you won't see me having the "barrier stealth credits" HW, because I feel I'll be able to pay up from Ghost Runner and Cloak's. Also Cache+ Aesop's is my idea of how you should play Nasir - having your credits spread all over the board, but not in your pool - so they are a must in my Nasir Decks

name: Bakemono (化け物) v1.6
description:
In japanese, 化け (bake) means to disguise oneself, to take another form, thus indicating a state of transformation. 化け物 (bakemono) would then translate into something like things that change.

My experience with Jinteki: Personal Evolution told me that every game unfolds in an entirely different way from the previous, and that's both an issue and an advantage at the same time.

An issue because it can be rather unpredictable and you need to adapt your strategy constantly. That could be said of about any kind of deck, but I think it's much more relevant in Jinteki, given how every player reacts differently to traps: some are brave and face check everything, others are more cautious and take baby steps, while others try to set up defenses before their offensive.

It can also be an advantage precisely because your opponent will hardly know what to expect and how to approach the game, especially in the early phases. Having plenty of different advanceable cards and Assets, as well as having a wide variety of ice, helps making things even more chaotic.

Now, about the Agenda selection:

  • Chronos Project is the big news from First Contact, and as many already guessed, it's a (very) welcome novelty for Jinteki: PE. Against a deck full of Net Damage, losing your Heap means losing the ability to heal yourself and recover your life points.
  • Fetal AI is an obvious choice, and can also be the one way to win by agenda points. If your opponent is at the end of his deck, with few cards left in hand he can be either too wary to try and steal a card with already 2 advancements on it, or just totally unable to survive stealing it. In the long run, this card can be your best friend.
  • Gila Hands Arcology is basically the main economy of this deck. In more than one game I scored this over an House of Knives, and the decision proved to be correct, paving the way for my victory. The deck doesn't need much money, but it still needs enough to pay for Snare! or Cerebral Overwriter.
  • House of Knives is easily the contender for the title of key card of the deck. If you aim to kill, scoring two of these can immensely facilitate that goal. Unless you already have one scored, though, GHA should be favored over this.
  • The Future Perfect serves to fill in the remaining points without needing another excessive number of agenda. It's unreliable, but can prove difficult to steal, so it's definitely better than the other options (even the new neutrals). Most of the time you'll be discarding it as soon as Jackson Howard comes around.

Assets are the thing that makes this deck work, and they all serve a very important function:

  • Cerebral Overwriter is a beast, and with the almost complete lack of defenses against Brain Damage, this one should be the target of your Mushin No Shin as soon as you get one. Scoring some BD on the Runner in early games is basically a game over.
  • GRNDL Refinery is another good target for Mushin when you're low on money, otherwise just advance it behind some ice (possibly Kitsune. When most of your advanced cards are traps, they'll think twice before checking one, at least until they see you got this one too.
  • Jackson Howard is essential, no alternatives. You need to be able to recycle stuff from the Archives, and especially to safely discard some Agenda when flooded.
  • Project Junebug is another killer, considering it amounts to 6 Net Damage when powered by Mushin. That makes it another very good option to store some advancement tokens to be later used with Trick of Light.
  • Shock! works wonders in this deck. Even one in Archives is usually enough to stop their runs there, and when you have 2 or 3 the extra ND might kill them, or anyway accelerate their demise. To be discarded as soon as possible.
  • Snare! continues to be the biggest danger for runners, even with 2 deluxes and 2 full cycles of data packs. As one friend said: "there's just nothing else so scary". Efficient and fairly expensive, always keep enough money to use it. Even when that means scoring an Agenda one turn later, or two.

The other two keys of the deck would be Mushin No Shin which is essentially your way to get free advancement tokens, and might actually be enough to kill a runner. Trick of Light is what you need to score Gila and/or House of Knives without any problems.

I hardly ever won by scoring 7 agenda point with this deck, but I can consistently kill my opponent. It does take quite a long time to do so, however, so the deck might not be the best option in a tournament.

It's very fun to play though, and with the new addition of Kitsune, it's even better.

By the way, in ancient japan the 狐 (kitsune, fox) was considered to be the true form of a bakemono, a shapeshifting monster. Let's hope we'll see some more of these mythic creatures!

name: Stirling's Nightclub
description: I am really excited to build this one in RL for league, I think 4 clicks late game makes iain a force to be reckoned with.

name: Human After All
description:
Human After All uses a Prepaid VoicePAD economy (Dirty Laundry, Lucky Find and Sure Gamble (obviously)) but is otherwise kind of a return to the classics for Anarch.

The ICEbreaker suite are the standard, super-efficient Anarch 'breakers, Datasuckers and Parasites. Medium and Nerve Agent are used to pressure the crap out of central servers and encourage the corp to install any cards they want to protect. After all, you're Whizzard: Master Gamer, so simply touching an asset is almost always enough to trash it.

The Prepaid VoicePADs are also there to make better use of a few powerful Events: Inside Job, Demolition Run and Scrubbed.

  • Inside Job is brutal. Snipe lightly protected remote servers, or rack up Medium/Nerve Agent virus counters by bypassing big ICE that you can't yet break in front of R&D/HQ.

  • Demolition Run is worth playing if you have even a couple counters on Medium or Nerve Agent. Trashing three cards is nothing to scoff at, especially if it's been discounted by Prepaid VoicePADs. This is probably best used as a disruption technique against HQ (trashing fast-advance tricks can be devastating to decks that rely on them), but don't be afraid to use it to dig in R&D.

  • Scrubbed is here to help save Datasucker counters and get rid of corp currents. They could be swapped for extra copies of Demolition Run, Knight or Grimoire.

Starting hands worth keeping involve economy cards and a Prepaid VoicePAD -- you want those out as early as possible to fully exploit them. Just don't get tunnel vision trying to get them all out.

name: SHIRKA : "Ulysses, the way back to earth has been wiped from
description:
"Ulysses, the way back to earth has been wiped from my memory"

Test Run = Two uses from an Overmind also hopefully ensuring it comes out when you want it to maximise memory usage.

Tempted by the idea of a Clone Chip to refresh the Overmind mid run if needed... Would that work?

...which this deck probably does not, but my hope would be that we'd be running Snitch and Blackguard earlish and swapping in Sneakdoor Beta later on.

Unusually for my decks we've got damage control, because i've recently been #Jinteki'd to hell and back :-)

Thoughts / Thinks?

name: THE PROFESSOR and AESOP in: THE WAY OF THE LOTUS (v1)
description:
This was inspired by Noise decks with Aesop's and Sahasrara to install programs for cheap. I figure, who better to install lots of programs for cheap than the Professor? When Cache is free to play and Aesop's is out it's a 6 credit boost, which is pretty nice.

What this deck needs in its opening hand is a Professional Contacts. Failing that, a Sahasrara isn't bad to get started with.

One thing I think it might need is Test Run for more options to get things back from the heap, or else maybe Levy.

This deck used to have Kati Jones in it, but I found I never really used her. There are enough discounts for programs that installing is typically cheap, and enough things to pawn to Aesop that I've typically had money to break ice when I had to. The problem right now is finding ice breakers, probably needs more tutoring.

name: Secret PassCODE, please?
description:
I am attempting to make a successful Encrypted Portals deck, that also takes advantage of some fast-advance features, such as Biotic Labor and Trick of Light.

Will make changes after a few plays.

name: Bioroid Intelligence Quotient
Exposed Andy
description:
Oh Andy, I love it when you expose ices like that... specially using that Blackguard to force the corp to rez them... yes, don´t stop my dear, you can combine it with your Snitch oh yeah, that´s it!

You can even expose more cards with Lemuria Codecracker to ensure we won´t have a bad time running on a remote server! Furthermore, thanks to the Unscheduled Maintenance we can force the corp to rez an ice knowing they won´t be able to stop us in another server!

You are the best dear...

name: Chaos Theory's Toolbox of Shenanigans. (Malaysian Nationals
description:
So what am i looking at?

Hit fast and hit hard with burst econ from sure gambles and dirty laundry but with enough sustainability to last late game should it drag out that far using magnum opus and toolbox. Basically a more streamlined version from an old professor deck i played way back when.

Influence spent on...?

Account Siphon. The reigning king from the criminal fraction. Quick cash to abuse and has the added bonus of adding insult to injury via 5 credit drain.

Legwork. The The Maker's Eye of the blue fraction, incredibly useful and this deck's only HQ pressure tool.

Planned Assault. The tutor for run events. Need a legwork or indexing? No worries. Planned assault has you covered.

Femme Fatale. Sentry breaker with the benefits of being able to bypass giant monsters.

Corroder. By far the best barrier breaker in the game(in my humble opinion).

Parasite. Eats up pop up windows and quandries for breakfast and removes all potential problems given enough time.

Hardware.

Clone Chip. to recur all your gimmicks, tricks and disposable programs. Has the added benefit of maybe bringing back your breakers after you get screwed seven ways to sunday by an ichi or grim.

R&D Interface. You draw one more card from R&D, what's not to love?

The Toolbox. A monster of a console, giving you recurring credits for your runs, additional memory and some link.

Programs and breakers.

Gordian Blade. Solid mid-range code gate breaker, the price is just right compared to it's bigger cousin Torch and with a greater base strength compared to ZU.13 Key Master.

Sharpshooter and Deus X. Keeping your precious programs safe and your beautiful brain in one piece from net damage. Choke on it jinteki.

Magnum Opus. Because only peasants(Anarchs) and dirty thieves(criminals) gain a single credit per click. #Shaper4lyfe.

Self-modifying Code. There is a fine line between being prepared and paranoid. This beautiful flower has saved my bacon from a countless number of snares and rototurrets.

Resources and events.

Same Old Thing. There is never enough of a good thing, even leaving the thing there alone as a potential threat would make the corp weary.

Diesel and Quality Time. *look at the entry about Magnum Opus but replace [credit] with [card draw].

Sure Gamble Burst econ. Never enough but we'll have to settle for 3.

Dirty Laundry. Gain credits or run. Whynotboth.jpg

Indexing. Avoid snares, deny potential ice/assets, plan around ambushes and traps, flood HQ with agendas for that future Legwork. The applications are almost limitless with little to no downsides.

Test Run. Tutor for programs which can be used for disposable stuff from the heap, or you can bring out Femme Fatale for a shaper version of Inside Job.

Levy AR Lab Access. AND NOW YOU BRING EVERYTHING BACK FOR AN ENCORE.

Anything i would replace or improve?

Stimhack and Vamp could replace Account Siphon being lower influence means more copies if consistency is an issue.

Originally the deck favored Daily Casts over Dirty Laundry for the long term investment but due to speed being an issue versus fast advance it was changed.

a 3rd copy of Self-modifying Code and maybe a second Parasite just to shutdown tiny annoying ice.

name: HB Old School. (Malaysian Nationals Top 8 2014 )
description:
Why these agendas in particular?

Accelerated Beta Test since it is easy to score with risky (not so much if you have Jackson Howard out) benefits, NAPD Contract to make each steal cost the runner money.

Priority Requisition and Eden Fragment are the best at what they do, giving a free rez or to make the subsequent ice cheaper to install.

Influence spent.

Tollbooth to make runs costly, Caduceus for an early defense, Lotus Field to stop andy from abusing yog and datasucker.

Jackson Howard because…well, it is Jackson howard, I don’t have to explain this one and a single copy of Edge of World for shenanigans and to put the fear of dying in an overconfident runner.

Assets and upgrades.

Adonis Campaign for a solid drip, Melange Mining Corp. for a huge burst and Private Contracts for the flexibility and high trash cost while Ash 2X3ZB9CY as a final line of defense.

ICE.

A good(if slightly costly) mix of ice with bioroids big and small.

Operations.

Hedge Fund for a nice burst. Subliminal Messaging as an additional minidrip and Interns to bring back my asset economy or draw and the occasional agenda lost due to noise/discard or a failed Accelerated Beta Test.

Anything I can improve on?

Plenty.

Cheaper ice(Neutral ice shall as Wall of Static or even a Quandary) since bioroids are almost impossible to rez when the runner is recurring siphons.

Swordsman can be used to fill Lotus Field if AI breakers are giving you major problems.

The 3rd copy of interns could be replaced with another subliminal messaging or private contracts since there has never really been a game where i needed a 3rd copy of it.

Eden fragment can be easily replaced with a Project Wotan or any other 3 pointer agenda. NAPD can be replaced Project Vitruvius or the upcoming Chronos Project if recursion is strong in your meta.

name: Reddit on shrooms.
description: NEVER AGAIN. Well... I dunno...

name: Guarding the Mid-game v1.0
Stronger Writer
Dec@Day.10 - Clicks Of Our Lives
description:
Dec@Day - Every identity, one day and deck at a time. It's like NaNoWriMo for Netrunner! More info in my profile.

Recent tournament darling Replicating Perfection almost builds itself: taxing ice on Centrals, with well-protected Agenda server, with False Leads and Nisei MK II making the click compression even worse. The strategy's incredibly strong, but I wanted to make running remotes even more difficult...hence, Hourglass.

Face-checking an Hourglass lets us stop the Runner's turn wholesale. Our other Code Gates--all of which get stronger with scored Encrypted Portals--strip a click, take two credits, or guarantee even worse. Now that our hapless Runner's run a central, their remote run is protected by a Eli 1.0 they can't afford to click through or an Ichi 1.0 ready to destroy their Decoder. Even if they survive that, Will-o'-the-Wisp still magicks away a breaker, and Caprice Nisei turns back time all by herself. Just like a soap opera, the Runner's going to spend a whole lot of time doing nothing at all--perfect.

Questions, comments or suggestions? Feel free--the entire reason I'm doing this is to increase my deck-building skills. Next up is Andy--who's just so hard to make a deck for...

Previous Dec@Day Decks:

  • 01 HB: EtF - Fix It in Beta
  • 02 An: Noise - Trojan Whale
  • 03 Ji: PE - Sword of Damocles
  • 04 Cr: Gabe - By Hook or By Crook
  • 05 NBN: MN - Watching Out for You
  • 06 Sh: Kate - The Art Thief
  • 07 We: BaBW - Surcharges Apply
  • 08 HB: ST - Talk Isn't Cheap
  • 09 An: Whiz - The Most Dangerous Game
  • R1 Ji: PE Sword of Damocles 2.0

name: The Engine
description:
Amazon Industrial Zone grants the Foundry's ID ability on the Corp turn, letting ICE get cranked out of the deck fast. Lots of ICE in the deck to offset the deck-thinning properties that The Foundry naturally causes.

The goal of the deck is to rapidly construct a deep remote using Alix, Melange, and/or Amazon Industrial at the base to fund the build-up. The occasional big ICE piece exists as a target for Priority Requisition or to dump cash from a run-away Melange Mining Corp into, otherwise the deck focuses on cheap and taxing options to make it very difficult to gain access.

Late game should use Caprice Nisei to make the scoring remote close to ironclad. 1x Aggressive Secretary is there to find tempo mid-game just as the Runner is feeling good about getting into the scoring remote.

name: Person of Interest v4.0
description:
Made some changes since the last version. For starters, I reverted back to Making News because Near Earth Hub just didn't support the ICE I needed to make the deck successful. I got rid of a few pieces of unnecessary ICE like Hunter and added some new favorites like Shadow and an additional Information Overload. Flare made its way back in because I needed an ICE that could do some serious damage if the Runner is unprepared. I added some previous Econ favorites back in along with Targeted Marketing because it's stupidly good against predictable and popular decks. Also new to the deck is Hive, making its debut. In recent matches, I've found that I could easily leave Hive with three or two ETR subroutines and then PsychoBeale for game, so I'm giving it a whirl temporarily.

Things I might change: Flare, because the 9 rez cost is brutal. Might add in a copy of Matrix Analyzer instead to have more tagging potential. I also might try and add more econ somehow, maybe Restructure or Successful Demonstration (since anyone who runs into a Data Raven early on ends the run to avoid bad stuff).

Always looking for more feedback, so feel free to comment!

name: SHIRKA : v0.2
description:
"Ulysses, the way back to earth has been wiped from my memory"

Test Run = Two uses from an Overmind also hopefully ensuring it comes out when you want it to maximise memory usage.

Tempted by the idea of a Clone Chip to refresh the Overmind mid run if needed... Would that work?

...which this deck probably does not, but my hope would be that we'd be running Snitch and Blackguard earlish and swapping in Sneakdoor Beta later on.

Unusually for my decks we've got damage control, because i've recently been #Jinteki'd to hell and back :-)

Thoughts / Thinks?

name: Smile Guide
description:
Archetype: Jinteki Cambridge (Kill PE)

My choices:

  • -2xEli/+2Sealed Vault - Without Vault - Account Siphoon and Vamp are the biggest vulnerability. I dont mind runner to be rich as long as I have some money. This deck runs smoothly when you're constantly at 10 credits = You can play PSI game, you can fire Snare and you can trigger overwriter in one turn.

  • +2xKomainu/-1xYagura-1xShiKyu - Komainu + House of Knives is a legitimate win condition against careless runner who likes to facecheck. I tend to play without rezzing ices (if the runner has already running money engine). I do rez them if they run aggresively without setting up any economy. Having Komainu in deck creates another layer of mind games - runners tend to be afraid of unrezzed ices. Finally in some situations Komainu is a fine taxing ice. About Yaguras: 2xYaguras in deck is enough I think. ShiKyu does not have any purpose in the deck for me. -1 Agenda point is a marginal effect.

  • -2xZaibatsu/+2xShock - This is the change I am not so sure about. I play in the meta without many expose so I benefit more from shocks as trap shells or as a passive archive protection (semi-countering Keyhole).

name: Holding All the Cards
description: Pretty standard Cerebral Imaging, but if it works, it works. I've always found the first few turns as CI to be terrifying, so this deck runs a few more ice than typical CI decks do. I think that losing the Subliminal Messaging in favor of more ice is just fine, a CI that can get off the ground has a rock-solid econ with or without the SubMessaging.
